ğŸ“– Vol 1: Foundations of Belief
The First Principle: Knowledge of His Existence, the Most High, and the first of the lights by which one is illuminated and the path of consideration that one traverses is what the Quran has guided to, for there is no explanation after the explanation of Allah, the Most High. And He, the Most High, said: 'Have We not made the earth a resting place (mihadan), and the mountains as pegs? And We created you in pairs, and made your sleep for rest, and made the night as a covering, and made the day for livelihood, and built above you seven strong ones, and made a blazing lamp, and sent down from the rain-clouds pouring water to bring forth thereby grain and vegetation and gardens of thick growth.' And He, the Most High, said: 'Indeed, in the creation of the heavens and the earth and the alternation of the night and the day and the ships which sail through the sea with that which benefits people, and what Allah has sent down from the sky of water and gave life thereby to the earth after its death and dispersed therein every kind of moving creature, and the directing of the winds and the clouds controlled between the sky and the earth are signs for a people who use reason.' And He, the Most High, said: 'Have you not considered how Allah created seven heavens in layers and made the moon therein a light and made the sun a lamp? And Allah has caused you to grow from the earth a growth, then He will return you into it and extract you an extraction.' And He, the Most High, said: 'Then do you see that which you emit? Is it you who creates it, or are We the Creator?' up to His saying: 'for the determined.' So it is not hidden from one who possesses the slightest bit of intellect, if he reflects with the least thought upon the content of these verses and turns his gaze upon the wonders of Allah's creation in the earth and the heavens and the marvels of the innate nature (fitrah) of animals and plants, that this amazing affair and precise arrangement cannot do without a Maker who manages it and an Agent who governs it and determines it. Rather, the innate nature (fitrah) of the souls (nufus) almost testifies to being subdued under His subjugation and directed according to His management. And for that reason, Allah, the Most High, said: 'Is there any doubt about Allah, Creator of the heavens and the earth?'

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din (Verbatim V3)

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Meditation
So what is the proportion of all the seas and the earth to the sky, while they are changing in proximity, and the heavens are firm, strong (shidad), preserved from change until the Book reaches its term? Therefore, He named it preserved, saying: 'And We made the sky a preserved roof' (Quran 21:32). And He, glorified be He, said: 'And We built above you seven strong ones (shidad)' (Quran 78:12). And He said: 'Are you a more difficult creation or is the sky? He constructed it, raised its height, and perfected it' (Quran 79:27-28). So look at the dominion (al-malakut) to see the wonders of might and majesty (al-jabarut). And do not think that the meaning of looking at the dominion (al-malakut) is by extending your sight to it so you see the blueness of the sky, the light of the stars, and their dispersion, for the beasts share with you in this looking. If this were the intended meaning, then why did Allah, exalted be He, praise Ibrahim (Abraham) by saying: 'And thus did We show Ibrahim the dominion (malakut) of the heavens and the earth' (Quran 6:75)? No, rather everything perceived by the sense of sight, the Quran expresses it as the kingdom (al-mulk) and the witnessed (al-shahadah), and what is hidden from the sights, it expresses it as the unseen (al-ghayb) and the dominion (al-malakut). And Allah, exalted be He, is Knower of the unseen and the witnessed, and the Compeller of the kingdom and the dominion (al-malakut). And no one encompasses anything of His knowledge except by what He wills, and He is Knower of the unseen, so He does not reveal His unseen to anyone except a messenger He has approved. So, O intelligent one, reflect on the dominion (al-malakut), perhaps the doors of the sky will open for you, and you will roam with your heart (qalb) in its regions until your heart (qalb) stands before the Throne of the Most Merciful. At that time, perhaps it is hoped for you that you reach the rank of Umar ibn al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, where he said: 'My heart (qalb) saw my Lord.' And this is because reaching the farthest cannot be except after surpassing the nearest, and the nearest thing to you is your soul (nafs), then the earth which is your abode, then the air enveloping you, then the plants and animals and what is on the face of the earth, then the wonders of the atmosphere, which is what is between the sky.

a.g: And made [therein] a burning lamp
And sent down, from the rain clouds, pouring water
That We may bring forth thereby grain and vegetation
And gardens of entwined growth.
Indeed, the Day of Judgement is an appointed time -
The Day the Horn is blown and you will come forth in multitudes
And the heaven is opened and will become gateways
And the mountains are removed and will be [but] a mirage.
Indeed, Hell has been lying in wait
For the transgressors, a place of return,
In which they will remain for ages [unending].
They will not taste therein [any] coolness or drink
Except scalding water and [foul] purulence -
An appropriate recompense.
Indeed, they were not expecting an account
And denied Our verses with [emphatic] denial.
But all things We have enumerated in writing.
"So taste [the penalty], and never will We increase you except in torment."
Indeed, for the righteous is attainment -
Gardens and grapevines
And full-breasted [companions] of equal age
And a full cup.
No ill speech will they hear therein or any falsehood -
[As] reward from your Lord, [a generous] gift [made due by] account,
[From] the Lord of the heavens and the earth and whatever is between them, the Most Merciful. They possess not from Him [authority for] speech.
The Day that the Spirit and the angels will stand in rows, they will not speak except for one whom the Most Merciful permits, and he will say what is correct.

And His saying, the Exalted: 'They will not speak except for one whom the Most Merciful (Ar-Rahman) has permitted and who says what is correct (sawaban).' {} And the Quran from its beginning to its end contains fears for whoever reads it with contemplation, and if there were not in it except His saying, the Exalted: 'And indeed, I am Forgiving (Ghaffar) to whoever repents (taba) and believes (amana) and does righteous work (amila salihan) then is guided (ihtada).' {} it would be sufficient, since He made forgiveness (maghfirah) conditional upon four conditions that the servant (al-abd) is incapable of fulfilling individually.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Remembrance of Death and the Afterlife
So He will say: 'Be dust.' And that is when the disbeliever says: 'Would that I were dust!' So you, O wretched one, on a day when you see your record empty of good deeds (Hasanat) in which your toil was prolonged, you will say: 'Where are my good deeds?' It will be said: 'They have been transferred to the record of your adversaries.' And you will see your record laden with evil deeds (Sayyi'at) in which your exertion in abstaining from them was prolonged and your effort in refraining from them intensified. You will say: 'O Lord, these are evil deeds I never committed.' It will be said: 'These are the evil deeds of the people whom you backbit, insulted, intended harm towards, and wronged in transactions, neighborliness, conversation, debate, discussion, study, and all other types of dealings.'

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Remembrance of Death and the Afterlife
So how would it be for you if your foot slipped and your regret did not benefit you, and you called out with woe and destruction and said: 'This is what I used to fear. Would that I had sent forth for my life! Would that I had taken a way with the Messenger! Woe to me! Would that I had not taken so-and-so as a friend! Would that I had been dust! Would that I had been a thing forgotten and out of sight! Would that my mother had not given birth to me!' And at that time, the fires snatch youâ€”we seek refuge in Allahâ€”and the caller calls out: 'Be driven into it and do not speak!' Then there remains no way except screaming, groaning, breathing, and calling for help. So how do you see now your intellect and these dangers before you? If you are not a believer in that, then how long your stay with the disbelievers in the depths of Hell will be!
